newsitem.title: USA: US Treasury's Summers warns Latam on inflation.
newsitem.headline: US Treasury's Summers warns Latam on inflation.

text.p: High rates of inflation damage markets and effectively undermine democracy by keeping the poorest people poor, Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers warned on Wednesday.

"Citizens will not trust governments that cannot maintain the value of their currencies and protect their savings," he said in a text prepared for delivery to an Inter-American Development Bank conference.
Latin America has felt the impact of high inflation many times. "Experience has shown that in countries where inflation is 30 percent or higher, the poor stay poor," Summers said.
Summers said experience showed there were no short-cuts to promote development and that state-run enterprises, including banks, seldom were of any help in doing so.

"While there are exceptions, the reality is that politics ususally intrude in the operation of a public enterprise and efficiency, financial performance and quality of service are often sacrificed," Summers said.

He urged privatizing state-owned companies and said that, in countries where that has been done, profits werew flowing into productive investments while basic services like electrical power supply and telephone systems have improved.
Summers said he was surprised to hear reports that some Russian economists favored relaxing stabilization policies and increasing government intervention in that country's economy.

He cautioned that easing Russia's reform efforts "would undermine the results of stabilization that which are only now beginning to be seen in the sharp reduction of inflation this year and a pickup in industrial production in some sectors."
The end result would be to harm the Russian poor and middle class who have borne the burden of stabilization and economic reform, Summers warned.
